items.title: Imagine Swimming — Parent & Me (96th & West End Ave)
items.content: Highly recommended swim program. Parent gets in the pool with baby. Can start from 8 weeks old. Parent-me classes ~$30/lesson up to 5 months, then ~$60. Free family swim on weekends with enrollment. Located at 96th St & West End Ave. Sundays at 12:30pm available. Multiple moms across all groups praised it.

items.title: Swim Jim (808 Columbus Ave) — 2 months+
items.content: Structured swim program at 808 Columbus Ave. Splash classes start at 2 months, Swimfants from 6 months. Warm pool. Pricey but structured curriculum. Highly regarded.

items.title: JCC Swimming (6 months+)
items.content: JCC swimming lessons start at 6 months. No membership required — non-member pricing available. Semester-based registration.

items.title: JCC Tummy Time Drop-In
items.content: Drop-in tummy time classes at the JCC. Fridays 12:15–1:00pm and Wednesdays 1:00–1:45pm. Also has Bubbling Babies swim class. Cost ~$20-25/class. Great for newborns and young babies. Also hosts infant CPR class (waitlist required).

items.title: Elliott's Gymnastics — Free Infant Class (0–6 months)
items.content: Free infant gymnastics and movement classes for ages 0–6 months on the UWS. Highly recommended by multiple moms. Great for early movement development.

items.title: Discovery Programs Baby Social — Free Wednesdays
items.content: Free drop-in baby social at Ansche Chesed synagogue. Wednesdays 12:15–1pm. For babies 0–9 months — songs, stories, and play. Great free option for newborns.

items.title: Ramblin' Dan Music (0+) — W86th Wednesdays
items.content: Popular music class for babies and toddlers from birth. W86th St location on Wednesdays mornings. Fun and lively sessions, widely recommended across multiple groups.

items.title: Katie's Corner / Dwyer Family Arts — Music (0+)
items.content: Music classes for babies through age 5+. Website: katiedwyermusic.com. Good for babies starting from birth.

items.title: Andy & Suzanna Music — Riverside Park (96th St, 10:30am)
items.content: Outdoor music class in Riverside Park at 96th St. Starts at 10:30am. Good warm-weather option.

items.title: Blooming Bebe — Infant Classes (2 months+)
items.content: Baby movement/activity classes starting at 2 months. Classes held in Central Park and other locations. Good for babies under 1 year.

items.title: Prenatal Yoga Center (PYC) — Baby & Me Yoga (72nd St)
items.content: Postnatal yoga with baby starting at 4–6 weeks postpartum. Baby-friendly — recordings sent if you miss class portions. Also offers ASL & Music classes (3 months+). Infant CPR class offered (waitlist). Located on 72nd St.

items.title: AURA Yoga + Pilates (239 W 72nd) — Mother's Circle
items.content: Prenatal and postnatal yoga, pilates, and sculpt classes at 239 W 72nd St. Mother's Circle program. Pre and postnatal certified instructors. Private sessions and Central Park outdoor classes also available.

items.title: The Lotus Method (408 Columbus Ave inside Cocoon) — Pre/Postnatal
items.content: Pre and postnatal functional strength training at 408 Columbus Ave (inside Cocoon). Pre-crawlers welcome in postnatal classes. Use code UWSFREE for a free first class. Highly recommended by local moms.

items.title: Fire Studio (W 115th) — Mom Strength Training & Yoga
items.content: Mom-focused strength training and yoga classes 5 days a week. Bring your baby to class. Located on W 115th St.

items.title: Eastside Westside Music Together (0+)
items.content: Music Together classes starting from birth. Offered on both UWS and UES. Popular program with good curriculum.

items.title: Little Maestros Music (3 months – 3 years)
items.content: Music classes for babies and toddlers ages 3 months to 3 years. Also Maestros University for 3–4 year olds.

items.title: Moosikikids Music (2 months+)
items.content: Baby music classes starting at 2 months. Recommended by UWS moms.

items.title: Musibambino — Baby & Toddler Music
items.content: Baby and toddler music class, recommended by UWS moms.

items.title: Dance with Miss Rachel — Baby Bob Music (10 weeks+)
items.content: Baby Bob music class for 10+ weeks. In-person NYC Elite / Miss Rachel sessions. Popular program widely recognized by babies.

items.title: Singin' Swingin' Shabbat — Rodeph Sholom (0–4 years)
items.content: Music and movement Shabbat program at Congregation Rodeph Sholom. Ages 0–4 years. Very welcoming to all families.

items.title: Soccer Stars (1 year+)
items.content: Soccer program for toddlers starting at 1 year. Good structured outdoor activity.

items.title: The Little Gym (4 months+)
items.content: Gymnastics and movement classes for babies 4 months and up.

items.title: NYC Elite Wiggle Worms (pre-crawlers, 2x/week)
items.content: Pre-crawler activity program offered twice a week. Good for babies before they start crawling.

items.title: Juliette and Ella's Playdate (3 months+)
items.content: Playdate-style movement class for babies 3 months and up.

items.title: Strand Bookstore Story Time (81st St — Sat & Sun, 12pm & 3pm)
items.content: Story time at the Strand Bookstore 81st St location. Saturdays and Sundays at 12pm and 3pm. Great for babies and toddlers, free.

items.title: Bloomingdale Library Family Time (Tuesdays 11:30am)
items.content: Free family story time at the Bloomingdale branch of the New York Public Library. Tuesdays at 11:30am.

items.title: Hans Christian Andersen Statue Story Time (Central Park)
items.content: Saturday story time at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park. Runs 11am until August 9. Check hcastorycenter.org for schedule.

items.title: AMC Lincoln Square — Mommy & Me Movies
items.content: Baby-friendly movie screenings at AMC Lincoln Square. Lowered volume, dimmed lights, stroller-friendly seating. Various films shown throughout the week.

items.title: Lenny Pearce Toddler Techno / Rave Events
items.content: Pop-up toddler rave / techno events around NYC. Fun, energetic events for toddlers who love to dance. Find tickets on Ticketmaster — search Lenny Pearce.

items.title: Play Street Museum (1 year+, reservation required)
items.content: Indoor play space for babies and toddlers from 1 year. Reservation required. Good for rainy days.

items.title: Children's Museum of Manhattan (CMOM)
items.content: Popular museum for babies and toddlers. Members can go early on the first Saturday. Library museum passes available to borrow for free admission. Great for rainy days.

items.title: New York Historical Society — Story Time & Crafts (3+ years)
items.content: Story time and crafts at the NY Historical Society. For children 3 years and up. Also has model trains display.

items.title: Home Depot Kids Workshop (1st Saturday every month, free)
items.content: Free children's building workshops at Home Depot. First Saturday of every month. Good for toddlers and kids.

items.title: Brooklyn Forest / Upper West Side Forest Kids
items.content: Outdoor nature and forest play programs for children ages 1–5. Brooklyn Forest and UWS Forest Kids chapters available.

items.title: New York Botanical Garden — Everett's Children's Garden
items.content: Children's garden at the New York Botanical Garden. Good for toddlers and older kids who enjoy outdoor exploration.

items.title: Sesame Place (2+ years, mostly water park)
items.content: Good for 2+ year olds, especially those who know Sesame Street characters. Mostly a water park. Tips: go early (opens at 10am), avoid weekends, bring sunscreen. Not much for under 2.

items.title: Free Riverside Park Music Class (Thursdays, 70th St)
items.content: Free music class on Thursdays in Riverside Park near 70th St. Check the Riverside Park website/events calendar for schedule.

items.title: Lincoln Center — Summer in the City Free Storytime
items.content: Free outdoor story time at Lincoln Center as part of the Summer in the City program. Check Lincoln Center website for dates.

items.title: Puppetsberg Shows (Pop-Up)
items.content: Pop-up puppet shows around NYC. Find schedule and ticket info via HiSawyer.com.

items.title: Tot Shabbat — Stephen Wise Free Synagogue (68th St)
items.content: Tot Shabbat programs for babies and toddlers at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue on 68th St. Very welcoming.

items.title: Rodeph Sholom — Baby & Toddler Programming
items.content: Congregation Rodeph Sholom on UWS offers great Jewish programming for babies and kids. Very welcoming to all families, including interfaith and same-sex couples.

items.title: Met Museum Playroom (81st St — free for walkers)
items.content: Free playroom at the Metropolitan Museum on 81st St. Great for toddlers who are walking. Good rainy day option. Free with museum admission.

items.title: Formula: By Heart — Good for Transition
items.content: By Heart formula recommended for transitioning from breastmilk. Well-tolerated by babies. Tip: give a new formula 6+ days before deciding if it works — allow time for adjustment.

items.title: Formula: European Options (Holle, Hipp, Kendamil)
items.content: European formulas highly recommended. Holle and Hipp available via formulaland.com or organicsbest.com. Hipp HA (hypoallergenic) version good for sensitive babies. Kendamil available at Target — organic, goat milk option available.

items.title: Bottles: Dr. Brown's Wide Mouth — Best for Gassiness
items.content: Dr. Brown's wide mouth bottles recommended over narrow for gassiness. Use without the inner straw insert if baby is not gassy — simpler and still effective. Widely used.

items.title: Bottles: Pigeon — Best for Breast-to-Bottle Transition
items.content: Pigeon bottles recommended for breastfed babies transitioning to bottle. The nipple shape mimics breast most closely. Multiple moms had success after other bottles failed.

items.title: Bottles: Comotomo — Good for Gassy Babies
items.content: Comotomo silicone bottles recommended for gassy babies. Soft, squeezable body. Available at most baby stores.

items.title: Bottles: Lansinoh Natural Wave Nipples
items.content: Lansinoh Natural Wave nipples immediately accepted by breastfed babies who refused other bottles. Worth trying for breast-to-bottle transition.

items.title: Bottles: EvenFlo Balance — Available at TJ Maxx Columbus
items.content: EvenFlo Balance bottles are a good affordable option available at TJ Maxx on Columbus Ave. Anti-colic design.

items.title: Magic Merlin Sleep Sack — Swaddle Transition
items.content: Helps bridge the swaddle-to-sleep-sack transition. Thick, restrictive design reduces the moro (startle) reflex. Use between traditional swaddle and arms-free sleep sack. Works well for babies who startle awake.

items.title: Halo Sleep Sack — Arms-Out Transition Sack
items.content: Good transitional sleep sack from swaddle to arms-free. Progress: both arms in → one arm out → both arms out. Works well after Magic Merlin stage.

items.title: Snoo Smart Sleeper — Rent or Buy Used
items.content: Smart bassinet that auto-responds to baby fussing. Can rent from Happiest Baby. Used Snoos go for ~$450 on Facebook Marketplace. Return when done. Very popular among NYC families.

items.title: Guava Lotus Travel Crib — Lightweight with Side Zipper
items.content: Lightweight travel crib with side zipper entry for easy access at night. Mattress may be too thin for some babies — bring an extra mat. Pairs well with Slumberpod for room sharing.

items.title: Slumberpod — Portable Blackout Cover for Cribs
items.content: Blackout canopy that fits over a pack-n-play or Lotus travel crib. Great for room-sharing while traveling. Compact enough to pack in a suitcase.

items.title: Doona — Stroller/Car Seat Combo (Good for Uber, Bad on Cobblestones)
items.content: Stroller that converts from/to a car seat. Very convenient for Ubers. However rides rough on cobblestone streets and NYC uneven sidewalks. Best for car-heavy travel destinations.

items.title: Cosco Scenera / Extend — Lightweight Travel Car Seat
items.content: Lightest car seat option for taxis/Ubers. Original Scenera discontinued June 2025 — replaced by Cosco Extend (same concept). Still available at Walmart. Maxi Cosi Romi is an alternative. Nuna Pipa Lite Rx also works without base for NYC use.

items.title: Baby Carriers: Solly Wrap, Ergo Embrace, Baby Bjorn Mini, Konny
items.content: Carrier recommendations from UWS moms: Solly Wrap (newborns, stretchy), Ergo Embrace (starts at 8 lbs, easy), Baby Bjorn Mini (easy solo, structured), Konny (easy like a wrap, soft, no fussing). Always follow TICKS safety guidelines. Check @letstalkbabywearing on Instagram.

items.title: Huckleberry App — Sleep Tracking & Nap Predictions
items.content: App that predicts optimal nap windows based on baby's wake times and tracks feedings, sleep, and diapers. Highly recommended by multiple moms for managing sleep schedules. Especially helpful for the 6-week sleep regression.

items.title: Hatch Go — Portable White Noise Machine
items.content: Portable white noise machine great for travel. Rechargeable, compact. Multiple volume and sound options. Popular travel companion.

items.title: Dr. Brown's Microwave Sterilizer + Sterilizer Bags
items.content: Microwave sterilizer bowl that fits a lot of bottles/parts at once. Also: Medela and Haakaa make microwave sterilizer bags that are great for travel or quick sterilization. Momcozy and Baby Brezza bottle washers also popular.

items.title: Lovevery Play Mat + Skip Hop Bandana Buddies
items.content: Lovevery play mat is widely popular. Pairs well with a foldable wooden playpen from Amazon to contain the space. Add Skip Hop Bandana Buddies chime toy for attachment. Good tummy time and play setup.

items.title: ToddleKind Puzzle Play Mats (Earth Clay color)
items.content: Premium foam puzzle piece play mats. Earth Clay color recommended as most neutral/aesthetically pleasing. Alternative to House of Noa mats. Easy to clean, soft underfoot.

items.title: Cardinal Gates SS30 — Top-Rated Stairway Baby Gate
items.content: Top-rated baby gate for stairs per Wirecutter. Hardware-mounted, very sturdy. Best option for top of stairs.

items.title: DaVinci Piper / Babyletto Kiwi — Compact Gliders for Small Apartments
items.content: Best glider options for NYC apartments: DaVinci Piper and Babyletto Kiwi are compact but still comfortable. Good for tight nursery spaces.

items.title: Spectra S2 Breast Pump — Most Popular
items.content: Spectra S2 is the most commonly recommended breast pump. Covered by most insurance. Quieter and more effective than basic hospital pumps for many moms.

items.title: Windi — Gas Relief for Babies
items.content: Windi is a small rectal gas relief tube for babies. Works quickly for trapped gas and fussiness. Used with Vaseline. Many moms swear by it for gassy, uncomfortable babies.

items.title: First Water Cups: Honey Bear Cup, Nuby Silicone, Contigo
items.content: Progression for first water cups: Honey Bear Cup (great for teaching straw drinking, squeeze to help), Nuby Silicone Cup (good starter at 6 months+), Contigo Kids Water Bottle (once straw mastered). All recommended by UWS moms.

items.title: Swimways Baby Spring Float — Pool Float
items.content: Great baby pool float for swim programs and hotel pools. Keeps baby upright in water. Good for parent-me swim classes.

items.title: Travel Sterilization: Milton Tablets + Collapsible Basin
items.content: For travel, Milton sterilizing tablets + a collapsible basin are the easiest hotel solution. No microwave needed. Soak bottles for 15 minutes, rinse, done. Compact to pack.

items.title: Portable Baby Gate for Travel (Twist-Knob, No Marks)
items.content: Portable twist-knob baby gate that doesn't leave marks. Folds into a single rod — fits in suitcase. Great for vacation home stairs. Amazon: https://a.co/d/9BHQvoI

items.title: Inflatable Bed Rail for Travel (PVC-Free)
items.content: PVC-free inflatable bed rail for toddlers in hotel beds. Inflates by mouth, deflates by rolling, fits in a tiny bag. Slide under bedsheet to create a high edge. Amazon: https://a.co/d/gK81uiL

items.title: NUULY + Rent the Runway — Maternity & Postpartum Clothes
items.content: NUULY rental service works well for maternity clothes — rotate styles without buying. Rent the Runway great for maternity work clothes, especially dresses and blazers when your body is changing size frequently postpartum.

items.title: Keith Magnussen — Curly Hair Specialist (79th & Broadway)
items.content: Curly hair specialist now at Curl Divinity salon on 79th and Broadway. Previously at DevaChan. Highly recommended for curly hair cuts and care.

items.title: Roz at Bumble & Bumble — Midtown Hair
items.content: Roz at Bumble & Bumble midtown recommended for hair styling. Good for all hair types.

items.title: Tess at Fox and Jane — East Village Hair
items.content: Tess at Fox and Jane salon in the East Village recommended for hair.

items.title: Salon Riz — Affordable Hair Color (UWS)
items.content: Recommended for brunettes wanting affordable hair color on the UWS. Good value.

items.title: Erin Gonzalez Photography — Family & Milestone Photos
items.content: UWS mom and professional photographer. Great for family photos, birthday and milestone photos, cake smash sessions. Website: eringonzalezphotography.com

items.title: Patricia Freire Photography — Great with Difficult Moods
items.content: Recommended NYC family photographer known for working well with babies and toddlers in difficult moods. Website: patriciafreirephotography.com

items.title: Manhattan Valley Pediatrics (MVP) — Overwhelmingly Recommended Practice
items.content: The most recommended pediatric practice among UWS moms across all groups. Located on 100th St. Multiple excellent doctors: Dr. Hoffman (very popular), Dr. Gati, Dr. Emanuel (Wednesdays/Fridays only — check schedule if returning to work), Dr. Grant, Dr. Nowell, Dr. Saha, Dr. Svensson. NP Rebecca also well-regarded. Always a doctor on call.

items.title: Nanny Elisa Baker — Night Nurse / Newborn Specialist
items.content: Nanny and night nurse with 27+ years experience. Child development specialist. Highly trusted. Contact: 917-260-9119.

items.title: Housekeeper/Nanny Irma — Reliable & Great with Pets
items.content: Housekeeper who is also great with babies and cats. $28–29/hr, flat rate $150 for 4 hours. Very reliable. Contact: +1 (646) 571-7731.

items.title: Frances Stewart Agency — Night Nurses (~$400/night)
items.content: Night nurse agency. Expect ~$400/night for a 12-hour shift. Background checked. Good for newborn period.

items.title: Broadway Babysitters — Reference & Background Checked
items.content: Babysitter service with reference and background checks. Website: broadwaybabysitters.com. Good for occasional babysitting needs.

items.title: UrbanSitter — Good in a Pinch
items.content: UrbanSitter app recommended for finding last-minute babysitters. Good for occasional or urgent needs.

items.title: Nanny Compensation Guide (NYC 2025)
items.content: NYC nanny pay standard: start $25–32/hr, guarantee 40 hrs/week, time-and-a-half over 40 hrs. Minimum $1/hr raise per year, +$2 for second baby. Reference the Park Slope Parents 2025 Nanny Survey for current rates. Include paid vacation time in offer. Nanny taxes (nanny tax) are required by law for household employees.

items.title: La Maternelle Daycare (64th St) — French Immersion
items.content: French-language daycare on 64th St. Generally loved by parents who toured. Has openings for 9 months to 2-year-olds. Worth touring early as spots fill fast. French immersion from infancy.

items.title: Goddard School (93rd St) — Infant Rooms
items.content: Goddard School on 93rd St has infant rooms. Positive experience from parents. Franchise model with generally consistent quality.

items.title: Vivvi Daycare (WEA at 92nd/93rd) — Favorable Ratios
items.content: New Vivvi location on West End Ave near 92nd/93rd St. Very favorable staff-to-child ratios. Good infant program.

items.title: Bright Horizons Columbus Circle — AVOID
items.content: AVOID: Bright Horizons at Columbus Circle was the site of a child abuse investigation and arrest. The 89th St Bright Horizons location has a very different reputation — that one is considered excellent.

items.title: Workplayce — Infant Daycare Option
items.content: Workplayce is an infant daycare option on the UWS. Worth touring and comparing with other options.

items.title: Metrokids Daycare (64th St, Riverside/WEA)
items.content: More affordable daycare option on 64th St between Riverside Dr and West End Ave. Lower cost than most UWS centers.

items.title: FemFirst Health (73rd & Broadway) — Melissa Jeski, Pelvic Floor PT
items.content: Highly recommended pelvic floor physical therapy. Melissa Jeski is excellent and has helped multiple moms through birth with no tearing using proper prep exercises. Located at 73rd & Broadway.

items.title: Zion PT (72nd St) — Cristina, Post-C-Section Specialist
items.content: Zion Physical Therapy on 72nd St. Cristina is highly recommended especially for post-C-section recovery. Note: cannot do online booking — must call to schedule. Full-body approach.

items.title: Spear Physical Therapy (75th St) — Tulsi, Nadia, Emily
items.content: Spear PT on 75th St recommended. Therapists mentioned: Tulsi, Nadia Filipic (also at midtown Spear), Emily Prader. Good for pelvic floor and general postpartum rehab.

items.title: Helen Kim — Women's PT (W72nd) — Whole Body Focus
items.content: Helen Kim on W72nd treats the whole body, not just pelvic floor. Good for chronic back pain from carrying and holding baby.

items.title: Pamela Morrison PT (65th & West End) — 70% Aetna Coverage
items.content: Pamela Morrison at 65th and West End Ave. 70% covered by Aetna for reimbursement. Good for those with Aetna insurance needing pelvic floor PT.

items.title: Anuja Mathew DPT — Women's Only Practice (Midtown)
items.content: Women's-only physical therapy practice in midtown. Out of network but highly recommended for pelvic floor and postpartum care.

items.title: Solstice PT (Midtown) — Erica, Lexi
items.content: Solstice Physical Therapy in midtown. Erica and Lexi mentioned as good therapists. Out of network.

items.title: Marianne Ryan — Pelvic Floor PT (UWS-Adjacent)
items.content: Well-regarded pelvic floor PT near UWS. Out of network. Recommended by multiple moms.

items.title: Cynergy / Wellness Den (UES) — Pilates Reformer PT
items.content: Physical therapy practice using Pilates reformer equipment. Located on UES but accessible via crosstown bus. Good for those who prefer Pilates-based rehab.

items.title: Liza at Rock-a-Bye Baby Sleep Consulting — Life Changer
items.content: Sleep consultant Liza from Rock-a-Bye Baby is described as a 'life changer' by multiple moms. Offers 'ask me anything' calls. Good for sleep training, schedule setting, and regressions.

items.title: Taking Cara Babies — Sleep Training Approach
items.content: Taking Cara Babies online program recommended for sleep training. Particularly helpful for room transitions and establishing sleep schedules. Course-based learning format.

items.title: Ashley Culver / Lift NYC — Personal Trainer (Pre/Postnatal)
items.content: Personal trainer recommended by multiple moms for pregnancy and postpartum strength training. Search 'Ashley Culver Lift NYC' for contact info.

items.title: Norvis — Postpartum Massage (UWS)
items.content: Highly recommended massage therapist for postpartum recovery. Located on the UWS.

items.title: Cocoon — Baby & Mom Classes Membership (Columbus Ave)
items.content: Cocoon on Columbus Ave offers a caterpillar membership for 3+ month babies. Access to music and other classes. Lotus Method operates out of this space. Good value for regular class-goers.

items.title: Leah Mari — Home Organizer
items.content: UWS home organizer. Send photos of your closets/spaces first before booking. Contact: leahmari.com@gmail.com

items.title: Anna's Cleaning NY — Highly Reliable
items.content: Highly recommended house cleaning service. Used by one UWS family for 8+ years. Website: annascleaningny.com

items.title: We Can Do It Worker Coop — Cleaning Service
items.content: Worker cooperative cleaning service recommended by UWS moms. Found very reliable through the coop model. Website: wecandoit.coop

items.title: Greg Minch at ALTOUR — Travel Agent (UWS-Friendly)
items.content: Travel agent recommended by UWS moms for booking family-friendly hotels and trips. Can find good rates and baby-friendly accommodations. Contact: 917-690-0775, greg.minch@altour.com

items.title: Dr. Gila Aaron (W68th St) — Highly Recommended OB
items.content: Highly recommended OB on W68th St. Well-regarded for both prenatal care and delivery. Delivers at Mount Sinai West.

items.title: Westside OB/GYN — Multiple Recommendations
items.content: Westside OB/GYN practice recommended by multiple moms across all groups. Several doctors praised. Convenient UWS location.

items.title: MFM Associates (UES) — Doula-Friendly, Natural Birth
items.content: Maternal-fetal medicine practice on UES. Delivers at Mt Sinai West. Known for respecting natural birth preferences and working with doulas. Allows patient advocacy during labor and delivery.

items.title: Mount Sinai West Birth Certificate — Timeline & Tips
items.content: Birth certificate from Mount Sinai West arrives in approximately 2 weeks. The form is filled out in the hospital at delivery. Keep the hospital paperwork for Social Security and passport applications.

items.title: Babywearing Safety: TICKS Guidelines
items.content: TICKS carrier safety rules: Tight (carrier should be snug), In view at all times, Close enough to kiss, Keep chin off chest, Supported back. Check @letstalkbabywearing on Instagram. Moby wrap good for newborns. Ring sling is highly adjustable. Always verify position before moving.

items.title: Breast-to-Bottle Transition: Bait & Switch Method
items.content: Start nursing baby for a few minutes, then switch to a bottle mid-feed. Baby is already in feeding mode and more likely to accept the bottle. Works better than cold-starting with a bottle.

items.title: Formula Transition: 'Appetizer Bottle' Method
items.content: Offer a small amount of formula first before breastfeeding. Baby is hungry and more likely to accept the new flavor/texture. Once accepted, gradually increase formula amount. Works well for stubborn latch babies.

items.title: Formula Transition Timeline: Allow 6+ Days Per Brand
items.content: Allow 6+ days before switching formula brands — baby's gut needs time to adjust. Take photos of dirty diapers to show pediatrician if you have concerns. Gradual 3:1 → 2:1 → 1:1 → full formula ratio works well over ~2 weeks.

items.title: Pumping Schedule at Work (3x/day, Every 3 Hours)
items.content: Return-to-work pumping schedule: 3 times a day around 10am, 12:30pm, and 3pm (roughly every 3 hours). 20–30 min per session. Between sessions: cold rinse and store pump parts in fridge — no need to sterilize each time. Pump bag tips: insulated bag with ice pack for milk storage.

items.title: Swaddle Transition: Magic Merlin → Halo → Arms-Free
items.content: Step-by-step swaddle transition: (1) Swaddled → (2) Magic Merlin sleep sack (both arms in) → (3) Halo sack with one arm out → (4) Both arms out. This gradual approach reduces sleep disruption from the moro (startle) reflex.

items.title: Mastitis Treatment: Cabbage Leaves, Ibuprofen & Antibiotics
items.content: Mastitis treatment combo: antibiotics from OB, ibuprofen for pain/inflammation, and cold cabbage leaves inside bra. Use any color cabbage EXCEPT red (it stains). Cabbage leaves provide natural anti-inflammatory relief. Change leaves when they wilt.

items.title: Rolling to Tummy at Night: What to Do
items.content: When baby starts rolling to their tummy at night: increase daytime tummy time so they get stronger and comfortable. Once baby can roll both ways independently, it is generally safe. Expect 4–7 days of adjustment. Don't flip them back each time — they need to practice.

items.title: Food Throwing: Offer 2–3 Pieces at a Time
items.content: When baby throws food from tray: offer only 2–3 pieces at a time instead of a full portion. Less to throw, better focus on eating. If throwing continues, take food away for a bit and try again. Normal developmental behavior.

items.title: Food Refusals: Change the Presentation
items.content: If baby refuses a food, try a different presentation. Examples: hard boiled egg whites as spears instead of chunks; slightly underripe banana in rounds instead of mashed. Temperature and texture changes can also help. Don't give up after one refusal — takes 10+ exposures.

items.title: Weaning Older Baby from Breastfeeding
items.content: Gradual weaning tips: replace nursing sessions one at a time with cuddles and warm milk in a cup. Have the other parent take over bedtime. Baby may protest for a few nights. Solid Starts website has detailed guidance. Don't offer but don't refuse for a gentle approach.

items.title: Baby Passport: Both Parents Must Appear in Person
items.content: Both parents must appear at the passport application appointment — no exceptions unless using a notarized DS-3053 form from the absent parent. Bring originals + copies of everything. Recommend AAA over USPS for passport applications (shorter wait, more organized). Take passport photo at home and print at Duane Reade. Apply for expedited processing if traveling within 3 months.

items.title: Baby Global Entry — Free Under 16, Apply Separately
items.content: Global Entry is free for children under 16. Apply as a separate individual (not tied to parent's membership). Can complete the interview at customs upon return from an international trip — no separate appointment needed initially.

items.title: NYC Taxis & Ubers — Car Seats Not Legally Required in Yellow Cabs
items.content: In NYC yellow cabs, car seats are legally not required for taxis (not enforced). For Uber/Lyft, it depends on the driver — some accept, some don't. Uber Car Seat service exists but is unreliable (often cancels). For peace of mind, bring a lightweight travel seat (Cosco Scenera/Extend) for longer rides.

items.title: 6-Week Sleep Regression — Normal, Temporary
items.content: The 6-week sleep regression is normal and temporary. Baby is going through a growth spurt and developmental leap. Tips: baby wearing/contact naps during the day, use Huckleberry app to track patterns, try a dream feed, accept the phase and don't try to sleep train through it.

items.title: Tick Protection with a Baby
items.content: Tick protection tips: Dress baby in long pants and sleeves. Spray shoes and clothes with DEET 15–30 min before going out (not on skin). Use picaridin wipes on ankle areas. Check every 1–2 hours in wooded/grassy areas. Carry a tick remover tool. Check all skin creases on baby after any outdoor time.

items.title: Airline Travel with Baby: Request Bassinet Early
items.content: Request a bassinet seat (bulkhead row) when booking — not all planes have them and they go fast. Bring baby's sleep sack as a familiar sleep cue. Board last (not during family boarding) so less time trapped in seat. Gate-check your stroller. Download entertainment before the flight.

items.title: Pack-n-Play Practice Naps Before Travel
items.content: Practice napping in a pack-n-play at home before any trip where baby will sleep in one. Familiarity with the sleep environment helps enormously on the road.

items.title: Reflux Management: Keep Upright, Gas Drops, Windi
items.content: For reflux: keep baby upright for 20–30 minutes after each feed. Mylicon gas drops (simethicone) can help. Use Windi for trapped gas. Elevate head of bassinet slightly. Report symptoms to pediatrician — some babies need a short course of medication.

items.title: Dr. Modi — Pediatric ENT / Tongue Tie Specialist
items.content: Dr. Modi recommended as a pediatric ENT who also handles tongue tie assessment and revision. Useful if breastfeeding difficulties are suspected to be related to latch/tongue tie.

items.title: Westside Pediatrics (90th & Columbus) — Dr. Mann, Goldberg, DeMattia
items.content: Well-regarded pediatric practice at 90th and Columbus Ave. Doctors: Dr. Mann (also a lactation consultant — very helpful for breastfeeding support), Dr. Goldberg, Dr. DeMattia. Full practice is excellent. Multiple families recommend.

items.title: Weill Cornell Pediatrics (84th & Broadway) — Dr. Odom, Kravitz, Nestler
items.content: Recommended Weill Cornell pediatric practice at 84th & Broadway. Dr. Elizabeth Odom may be on maternity leave — check. Dr. Amanda Kravitz, Dr. Elizabeth Nestler, Dr. Jane Rossini, Dr. Cohen also well-reviewed.

items.title: Weill Cornell Pediatrics (72nd St) — Dr. Erick Rosenberg
items.content: Dr. Erick Rosenberg at Weill Cornell pediatrics on 72nd St. Recommended by UWS moms.

items.title: Our Kids Pediatrics (70th St) — Dr. Gidwani
items.content: Dr. Gidwani at Our Kids on 70th St is highly recommended. Was on rotation at birth for multiple families. Nurses are very responsive by email. First 1-week appointment was thorough and reassuring.

items.title: Tribeca Pediatrics (89th & Columbus) — Dr. Sasala
items.content: Dr. Sasala at Tribeca Pediatrics' 89th St & Columbus Ave location. Recommended.

items.title: Pediatric GI: Dr. Nancy Pittman (UES) & Dr. Gordon (Weill Cornell)
items.content: For pediatric GI issues: Dr. Nancy Pittman on the UES is highly recommended. Dr. Gordon at Weill Cornell UES also well-regarded. Worth crossing the park for GI specialists.

items.title: Pediatric PT: Alyson Cerbone (Weill Cornell, 525 E 68th)
items.content: Pediatric physical therapist at Weill Cornell, 525 E 68th St. Recommended for early motor development concerns or torticollis.

items.title: Tacombi — Best for Families with Babies & Toddlers
items.content: Top recommendation for dining out with a stroller. Casual Mexican, spacious layout, kid-tolerant atmosphere. Multiple UWS moms agree it's one of the best options.

items.title: Ellington in the Park — Riverside Park Biergarten/Café
items.content: Outdoor café and biergarten inside Riverside Park. Opens seasonally (from ~April 24). Coffee shop section open year-round. Great for meet-ups with strollers. Walk right in from the park path.

items.title: Mermaid Inn — Large Space, No Changing Table
items.content: Large restaurant layout, good for strollers especially during early dinner/happy hour. Seafood focus. Note: NO changing table or family bathroom — plan accordingly.

items.title: Nice Matin — Good If Not Crowded
items.content: French-Mediterranean on the UWS. Good for strollers at off-peak times. Can get tight when crowded.

items.title: Pecora Bianca — Good If Not Crowded
items.content: Italian restaurant, good for strollers when not too crowded. Nicer atmosphere but manageable with a baby.

items.title: French Roast — Casual Brasserie, Stroller OK
items.content: Casual French brasserie, stroller-friendly. Good for a relaxed meal out on the UWS.

items.title: Westville — Outside Seating with Strollers
items.content: Good outdoor seating option for strollers. American comfort food. Easy with a baby when sitting outside.

items.title: La Bomboniera (82nd & Amsterdam) — Decent Space
items.content: New location on 82nd at Amsterdam/West Side. Decent space for strollers. Worth trying for a casual meal.

items.title: Vanguard Wine Bar (Amsterdam between 68th & 69th)
items.content: Nice wine bar on Amsterdam Ave between 68th and 69th St. Good meet-up spot in the evening. Stroller-friendly.

items.title: Pier I Café — Riverside Park, Great Outdoor Meetup Spot
items.content: Riverside outdoor café at Pier I in Riverside Park. Great for warm weather meetups with strollers. Walk-up style, open air.

items.title: Covacha, Lokal, Asset — Other UWS Stroller-Friendly Spots
items.content: Other stroller-friendly spots mentioned by UWS moms: Covacha (Latin-inspired), Lokal (staff welcoming with strollers), Asset (casual, good space).

items.title: Picky Barista — Coffee on 72nd (North Side, Broadway to WEA)
items.content: Coffee shop on the north side of 72nd St between Broadway and West End Ave. Good for a stroller-friendly coffee stop.

items.title: Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial (72nd & Riverside) — Popular Meetup Spot
items.content: The Eleanor Roosevelt statue at 72nd & Riverside Dr is a popular UWS mom meetup spot. Shaded, open area, stroller-friendly path access to Riverside Park.

items.title: Soldiers & Sailors Monument (89th & Riverside) — Meetup Point
items.content: The Soldiers & Sailors Monument at 89th St and Riverside Drive is used as a meetup reference point for Riverside Park walks.

items.title: Playground Water Features Map (Summer)
items.content: NYC parks with water play features for babies and toddlers: Dinosaur Playground (97th & Riverside — NOTE: closed 2025 for renovation), Hippo Playground, River Run Playground, Safari Playground in Central Park at 90th (sprinklers), Tarr-Coyne Tots (68th & CPW, good for under 20 months), Waterline Square (60th). Full list at nycgovparks.org/facilities/sprayshowers

items.title: Dinosaur Playground (97th & Riverside) — Closed 2025
items.content: HEADS UP: Dinosaur Playground at 97th & Riverside Drive is closed in 2025 for renovation. Check NYC Parks website for reopening date.

items.title: Safari Playground (Central Park, 90th St) — Sprinklers
items.content: Safari Playground in Central Park at 90th St has a good sprinkler section. Good for summer water play. Can get crowded on hot days — go early.

items.title: Buy Nothing Groups — UWS (Facebook, by Cross Streets)
items.content: UWS Buy Nothing groups on Facebook are organized by cross streets. Search for groups covering 76th–90th St, 91st–100th St, etc. Great for baby gear donations and finds. Also try the UWS Mom groups directly.

items.title: St. Francis Thrift Store — Donation Center (7 days, 11am–5pm)
items.content: St. Francis Thrift Store accepts donations of baby gear and clothing. Open 7 days a week, 11am–5pm. Good for donating items baby has outgrown.

items.title: St. Paul and St. Andrew Church (86th & West End) — Baby Item Donations
items.content: St. Paul and St. Andrew Church on 86th St & West End Ave accepts donations of baby items and clothing.

items.title: Best Spots for Toddler Bike & Scooter Practice
items.content: Best paved areas for toddler scooting/biking: Riverside Park above 97th St (long, less crowded), 77th & Amsterdam Park (circular loop track), Safari Playground in Central Park (paved path but crowded), flat area near Tavern on the Green for open space practice.

items.title: Thanksgiving Parade Viewing Tip: Float Inflation Night
items.content: For a crowd-free Macy's Thanksgiving Parade experience: floats are inflated and parked on CPW between 81st and 86th the evening before (Wednesday night). Note: this has gotten more crowded in recent years as it went viral, but still less than parade day.

items.title: NYPL Library Museum Passes — Free Admission to CMOM and More
items.content: The New York Public Library offers museum passes through the library card system. You can borrow passes for CMOM (Children's Museum of Manhattan), the Met, and other museums for free. Check the NYPL website or ask your local branch librarian.

items.title: Morningside Park — Good for 110th Area Moms
items.content: Morningside Park recommended for families living in the upper UWS around 110th St. Quieter than Riverside Park and Central Park, good playground, less crowded.

items.title: Community Garden on W87th — Relaxing Outdoor Sitting Spot
items.content: The community garden on W87th St is a good quiet spot to sit while baby naps in stroller. Peaceful, shaded area.

items.title: TJ Maxx on Columbus Ave — Baby Gear Bargains
items.content: TJ Maxx on Columbus Ave sometimes carries discounted baby bottles (EvenFlo Balance), play items, and baby gear. Worth a browse when looking for deals.

items.title: Toddler-Friendly Bike Path: Riverside Park above 97th
items.content: The esplanade and path in Riverside Park above 97th St is the least crowded long paved stretch for toddler bikes and scooters. Less foot traffic than lower park sections.

items.title: City Center Free Family Activities (130 W 56th)
items.content: City Center at 130 West 56th St offers free family programming. Enter via 'communityday' for free access.

items.title: Waterline Square (60th St) — Sprinklers & Outdoor Play
items.content: Waterline Square at 60th St has sprinkler water play area for toddlers. Good for summer trips downtown from UWS.

items.title: Family-Friendly Travel: Baby-Friendly Hotels & Resorts
items.content: Resort tips from UWS moms: Atlantis Bahamas good for 2+ years (water park focused). Club Med has well-regarded baby-club programs (dedicated baby care staff). Calcot Hotel in the Cotswolds (UK) is very family-friendly. Kinder Hotels in Austrian Alps are specifically designed for families with young children.

items.title: Morningside Heights / 110th — Good Walking Loop
items.content: Morningside Heights area around 110th has a good stroller walk loop: Morningside Park + up to Riverside Park connects via 116th. Less crowded than the main UWS strip.

items.title: Fountain Bookshop Story Time (Washington Heights/Fort Tryon)
items.content: Fountain Bookshop offers story time every Tuesday and Friday at 10:15am. Located in Washington Heights/Fort Tryon area — a trip uptown but worth it for book lovers.

items.title: Nanny Shares — Tips for Setting One Up
items.content: Nanny share tips: Both families should agree on a consistent schedule and location. Nanny earns ~15–20% more than solo care. Split cost between families saves ~30–40% each. Best when babies are close in age. Use a written nanny share agreement covering sick days, holidays, and schedule changes.

items.title: Bright Horizons Backup Care — Same-Day Booking via Care.com
items.content: Bright Horizons offers employer-sponsored backup childcare. Can book same-day through Care.com if your employer has a contract. Good for sick nanny days or daycare closures.

items.title: Solid Starts App — Best Baby Food Introduction Resource
items.content: Solid Starts app and website is the go-to resource for introducing solid foods — shows exact age-appropriate serving sizes, prep methods, choking vs. gagging info, and allergen introduction guides. Free tier is very useful.

items.title: Allergen Introduction: Do One at a Time, Wait 3 Days
items.content: When introducing the 9 major allergens (milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts, wheat, soy, fish, shellfish, sesame): introduce one allergen at a time and wait 3 days before introducing another. This allows identification of which food caused a reaction. Best done in the morning so you can monitor during the day.

items.title: Choking vs. Gagging — Understanding the Difference
items.content: Gagging is normal and protective — loud, baby is in control. Choking is silent — baby cannot breathe. Do NOT intervene during gagging — it is baby learning. Do intervene immediately for choking. Take an infant CPR class before starting solids (JCC offers these, waitlist required).

items.title: Postpartum Hair Loss — Expect it at 3–6 Months
items.content: Postpartum hair loss typically peaks around 3–6 months postpartum. Normal due to hormone shifts. No strong product recs from the group — most say it resolves on its own. Biotin supplements may help. Hair typically returns to normal by 12 months.

items.title: Baby Social Security Card — Apply Before Pediatric Appointments
items.content: Apply for baby's Social Security card at the hospital or shortly after birth. The card is needed for insurance enrollment, tax purposes, and passport applications. Processing takes ~2–4 weeks by mail.

items.title: Medela Haakaa / Silicone Pump — Easy Milk Collection
items.content: Haakaa silicone pump attaches via suction to the opposite breast during nursing to passively collect letdown milk. Great for building a freezer stash without extra pumping sessions. Very affordable.

items.title: Formula: Bobbie Organic — Gentle Option
items.content: Bobbie Organic formula well-tolerated for sensitive stomachs. Not every baby responds the same — allow 1 full week before judging. Enfamil Gentlease reportedly less tolerated than Bobbie by some.

items.title: Solly Wrap — Stretchy Newborn Carrier
items.content: Solly Baby wrap recommended for newborns. Lightweight, soft jersey fabric. Good for the fourth trimester when baby wants constant contact. Stretchy design means no extra panels.

items.title: Infant CPR Class — JCC Offers (Waitlist Required)
items.content: Infant CPR classes are offered at the JCC on the UWS. Waitlist required — sign up early. Highly recommended to complete before starting solids at 6 months.

items.title: NYC Spray Shower Locator — Official Parks Map
items.content: Find all spray showers and water play areas in NYC via the official NYC Parks website: nycgovparks.org/facilities/sprayshowers. Filter by borough and neighborhood.

items.title: Tarr-Coyne Tots Playground (68th & CPW) — Best for Under 20 Months
items.content: Tarr-Coyne Tots playground at 68th St & Central Park West has water play features. Best for babies and toddlers under 20 months — low to ground, gentle spray. Good for summer cool-downs.

items.title: Nap Transition Tips: 3 Naps to 2, 2 Naps to 1
items.content: Nap transition signs: baby takes a long time to fall asleep for one nap or skips it entirely consistently for 1–2 weeks. Don't rush the transition — some babies drop a nap slowly. Huckleberry app helps predict optimal wake windows during transitions.

items.title: Iron-Rich Foods for Baby — Critical at 6 Months
items.content: Iron is the most critical nutrient when starting solids at 6 months as breastmilk iron decreases. Prioritize: pureed beef/lamb, chicken, tofu, lentils, fortified oatmeal, beans. Pair with vitamin C foods to boost absorption.

items.title: Starting Solids: 6 Months, Skip Purees or Combine?
items.content: Both BLW (baby-led weaning with soft finger foods) and purees are valid approaches — or combine both. Key is texture variety and not delaying past 6 months. Offer a variety of flavors early. Solid Starts app has a comprehensive food database with age-specific prep guides.

items.title: Sleep Training Methods — Ferber, Fading, Chair
items.content: Common sleep training methods discussed by UWS moms: Ferber method (graduated extinction, check-ins), Chair method (stay in room, move farther each night), Fading (gradually reduce assistance). Most moms waited until 4–6 months and got pediatrician sign-off first. Taking Cara Babies and Liza at Rock-a-Bye Baby Sleep both recommended.

items.title: Circumcision Care and Healing Timeline
items.content: Post-circumcision care: apply petroleum jelly with each diaper change for 7–10 days. Keep dry. Healing typically complete by 10–14 days. Call pediatrician if redness spreads or there's unusual discharge. Detailed care sheet provided at hospital.

items.title: Baby Bjorn Mini — Best Solo-Parent Carrier
items.content: Baby Bjorn Mini recommended as easiest carrier to put on solo without help. Structured design, no wrapping needed. Works from birth (~8 lbs) up to about 12 months.

items.title: Konny Baby Carrier — Easy On/Off Like a Wrap
items.content: Konny carrier is easy to put on solo (like pulling on a shirt), soft like a wrap but no lengthy wrapping. Good for quick carries around the house or short outings.

items.title: Prenatal Yoga Center (PYC, 72nd St) — Postnatal Classes
items.content: PYC at 72nd St offers postnatal yoga. Baby-friendly — recordings sent if you miss portions. Also offers infant ASL & music classes for 3 months+. Popular with UWS moms for community as much as fitness.

items.title: Dr. Julia Meisler — Weill Cornell OB
items.content: Extremely well-reviewed OB at Weill Cornell. Delivered multiple babies for families in these groups. Strong consensus recommendation across all groups.

items.title: Dr. Nabizadeh — Weill Cornell OB (C-Section Specialist)
items.content: Highly recommended OB at Weill Cornell. Multiple moms praised her for both routine prenatal care and delivery including scheduled and emergency C-sections.

items.title: Oula Midwifery Practice — Prenatal Care
items.content: Oula is a recommended midwifery/OB hybrid practice. Good for those wanting a collaborative care model with midwives and OBs together.

items.title: Dr. Anna Rhee & Dr. Robin Brown — Mount Sinai West OBs
items.content: Dr. Anna Rhee and Dr. Robin Brown at Mount Sinai West are recommended OBs. Both well-regarded for prenatal care and delivery.

items.title: Dr. Brar-Kripalani & Dr. Worell — Mount Sinai Union Sq Practice
items.content: Highly recommended OB practice at Mount Sinai Union Square. Delivers at Mt Sinai West. Dr. Worell specifically praised for handling emergency C-sections. Full practice is loved.

items.title: Mobile Hairstylist — Comes to Your Apartment (~$80)
items.content: Mobile hairstylist who comes to your apartment. Charged ~$80 for a haircut. Convenient for new moms who can't easily get out. Ask in the community group for the contact info.

items.title: Playground Pups — Dog Training (W92nd & Amsterdam)
items.content: Dog training service at W92nd & Amsterdam Ave. Good for families managing a dog alongside a new baby.

items.title: Imagine Swimming — Free Family Swim Weekends (with Enrollment)
items.content: Imagine Swimming offers free family swim on weekends for enrolled students. Great bonus — parents and siblings can come. Check their website for current session schedules.

items.title: River Run Playground — Water Play Feature
items.content: River Run Playground on the UWS has a water play feature. Good for summer visits. Check NYC Parks for exact hours when water features are running.

items.title: Hippo Playground — Water Features
items.content: Hippo Playground on the UWS has water play features in the summer. Good for toddlers.

items.title: Doula Support — Benefits for Labor and Delivery
items.content: Multiple moms strongly recommend having a doula. Doulas provide continuous labor support, help advocate for birth preferences, and improve outcomes (reduced C-section rates, shorter labor). Many UWS practices are doula-friendly — confirm with your OB beforehand.

items.title: Postpartum Depression & Anxiety — Resources
items.content: Postpartum mood disorders affect ~1 in 5 new moms. Signs: persistent sadness, anxiety, intrusive thoughts, inability to sleep even when baby sleeps, feeling detached. Resources: Postpartum Support International (postpartum.net, helpline available), therapy referrals through OB or pediatrician. Don't wait to ask for help.

items.title: Spectra Pump Parts & Flanges — Get the Right Fit
items.content: Flange size matters significantly for pumping comfort and output. Default flanges are usually too large. Measure at home or ask an IBCLC lactation consultant. Pumpin Pal angled flanges recommended for comfort. Aeroflow Breastpumps handles insurance claims for Spectra S2.

items.title: IBCLC Lactation Consultants — Finding One in NYC
items.content: Recommended ways to find an IBCLC lactation consultant in NYC: Ask your OB or midwife for a referral, check ilca.org for a certified directory, hospital LC often available in the first days. Many are covered by insurance (ACA-required coverage for lactation support). In-home visits available.

items.title: All My Children Daycare (UWS) — Director Carly
items.content: All My Children Daycare on the UWS. Director named Carly. Mentioned by a UWS mom as an option worth exploring.

items.title: Night Sweats & Postpartum Hormone Changes — Normal
items.content: Heavy night sweats in the first weeks postpartum are normal as estrogen drops and fluid is shed. Protect mattress with a waterproof cover. Typically resolves by 2–4 weeks. If ongoing or fever accompanies, contact OB.

items.title: Nuna Pipa Lite Rx — No-Base Car Seat Option for NYC
items.content: The Nuna Pipa Lite Rx can be used without a base — good for taxis and Ubers in NYC. Includes an anti-rebound bar. One of the lightest infant car seats available.

items.title: Ring Sling Carrier — Adjustable for Newborns
items.content: Ring sling carriers are highly adjustable and compact. Good for newborns and breastfeeding on the go. Slight learning curve but very convenient once mastered. Check @letstalkbabywearing for tutorials.

items.title: Ellington in the Park — Opening Season Starts Late April
items.content: Ellington in the Park inside Riverside Park typically opens for its outdoor beer garden/café season around April 24. Coffee shop portion may open earlier. Great stroller meetup spot — paths connect directly from the park.

items.title: Returning to Work: Pumping Room Rights (NYC Law)
items.content: NYC and federal law require employers to provide a private, non-bathroom space for pumping and break time for expressing milk for up to 3 years postpartum. You have the right to request this from HR. If denied, contact NYC Commission on Human Rights.

items.title: Dream Feed — Adding a Late-Night Feed to Extend Sleep
items.content: A dream feed is a late-night feed (10–11pm) given while baby is mostly asleep, before you go to bed. Can help some babies sleep a longer stretch. Not all babies respond — try consistently for a week before deciding if it helps.

items.title: Teething Relief: Frozen Washcloth, Teething Rings, Motrin
items.content: Teething tips from UWS moms: frozen wet washcloth to chew on, silicone teething rings (refrigerated, not frozen solid), Sophie la Girafe is popular. For severe discomfort: infant Motrin (after 6 months) or Tylenol — ask pediatrician. Avoid teething gels with benzocaine.
